data.title: Add critical natives for some hot methods
data.body:
Similar to https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/4021 but more explicit.

Adds support for critical natives, which reduces the overhead of jni-calls.
Critical natives are supported on Hotspot JVMs since Java7. See also [this answer on stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36298111/is-it-possible-to-use-sun-misc-unsafe-to-call-c-functions-without-jni/36309652#36309652).

This PR shouldn't break any code.
Critical natives have been tested on Mac OS X 64bit, Linux 32 and 64bit, Windows 32 and 64bit.
# How to use
1. Ensure that your method can be used as a critical native. This means that it is **static**, **non-synchronized** and only has **primitives** or **primitives arrays** as arguments.
2. The method also can not use the normal `JNIEnv*` or  `jclass` arguments

Support for critical natives has to be _explicitly_ added.
So for example, if we have this method:

``` java
private static native void foo(int anInt, float[] anArray); /*
  foo(anInt, anArray);
*/
```

jnigen would create this:

``` c
JNIEXPORT void JNICALL Java_[package]_[class]_foo(JNIEnv* env, jclass clazz, jint anInt, jfloatArray obj_anArray)
{
  float* anArray = (float*)env->GetPrimitiveArrayCritical(obj_anArray, 0);
  foo(anInt, anArray);
  env->ReleasePrimitiveArrayCritical(obj_anArray, anArray, 0);
}
```
## **That's is the way it currently works.**

This PR adds support for generating critical natives.
To do so, we have to add a new (java) method:

``` java
private static native void foo_JNICritical(int anInt, int anArrayLength, float[] anArray); /*
  foo(anInt, anArray);
*/
```

this method is then used for generating a critical native, so it becomes this:

``` c
JNIEXPORT void JNICALL JavaCritical_[package]_[class]_foo(jint anInt, jint anArrayLength, jfloatArray anArray)
{
  foo(anInt, anArray);
}
```
## **What changed compared to the non critical version:**

Compare:
Normal version:

``` java
private static native void foo(int anInt, float[] anArray);
```

vs.
Critical version

``` java
private static native void foo_JNICritical(int anInt, int anArrayLength, float[] anArray);
```
1. A critical version has the same name plus `_JNICritical` to identify it as a critical native.
2. You **have to** add a new parameter of type `int` before every primitive array.
   The parameter contains the length of the primitive array. 
   **If you don't do this your critical native will probably _not_ be called!**
# Which functions benefits from it

Functions that do relatively little work in the native code benefit from it, since the jni overhead is greatly reduced.
That's why the various methods of `Matrix4` (`mul`, `rot`, ...),which all need to pass primitive arrays, are about 2 times faster.
Some methods of `BufferUtils` also gained support for critical natives, but I didn't benchmark how much they're faster and as is the case with `Matrix4` only methods that pass primitive arrays gained support.

data.title: Allow tap count reset on ClickListener
data.body: I was having a hard time working around this missing method. There are cases where I have a widget that does something different with a drag than with a double click. But if I quickly drag and then click soon after the drag, it still counts as a double click. By double click, I mean checking `if (getTapCount() == 2)` in the `click` method.

data.title: Vertical Group crashes randomly when actors are added and removed
Make HttpResponseListener usable by multiple requests by including the HttpRequest in the parameters of each method
'Gradle: Execution failed for task' when using BaseGameUtils from Google
data.body:
#### Issue details

When trying to run a libgdx project made with the new version of libgdx and new gdx-setup with the BaseGameUtils from the android basic samples added the compilation fails with the following error:

```
Error:Gradle: Execution failed for task ':BaseGameUtils:extractReleaseAnnotations'.
> originalComplianceLevel
```
#### Reproduction steps/code
1. Create a new LibGDX project in gdx setup.
2. Add in BaseGameUtils following the steps in the 'Intellij setup' section of https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Google-Play-Game-Services-in-LibGDX
3. Run the default android run configuration created by the setup
#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies

gdxVersion = '1.9.3'
roboVMVersion = '2.1.0'
com.mobidevelop.robovm:robovm-gradle-plugin:2.1.0 (Maybe this is relevant)
#### Stacktrace

``` java
I doesn't give a stacktrace and I'm not sure how to make it give one, sorry.
```
#### Please select the affected platforms
- [X] Android
- [ ] iOS
- [ ] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

data.title: Add useful method
data.body: Useful method to manage quote replacement in paths

data.title: Enable/Disable drag and drop?
data.body:
How can I enable or disable a DragAndDrop object?
In my case I have a card hand and I want to enable or disable the ability to drag and drop cards whenever I want.

data.title: RoboVM Gradle Plugin: Execution failed for task ':android:lintVitalRelease'. > originalComplianceLevel
data.body:
Originally reported here: https://github.com/MobiDevelop/robovm/issues/13. Reposted here with permission from @MobiDevelop.
#### Issue details

Using the latest `gdx-setup.jar`, creating a new default LibGDX project using gdx-setup.jar, running `./gradlew clean build` causes build failure with all current versions of @MobiDevelop's RoboVM Gradle plugin.

There is some sort of conflict between the RoboVM Gradle plugin & the Android Gradle plugin. If you remove either one of these two plugins from the buildscript, the build will succeed. Changing dependency and/or plugin versions did not cause any change, as you can see below.

Error message:

```
Execution failed for task ':android:lintVitalRelease'.
> originalComplianceLevel
```

Root cause:

```
Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: originalComplianceLevel
```

Related issue: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/adt-dev/2LnnpF-t6XA
#### Reproduction steps/code
1. Download & run the latest `gdx-setup.jar`.
2. Create a new default LibGDX project.
3. Configure the com.mobidevelop robovm gradle plugin in the root `build.gradle`, as described [here](https://github.com/MobiDevelop/robovm/blob/master/plugins/gradle/README.md#usage).
4. Run `./gradlew clean build` on the project.

root `build.gradle`:

``` groovy
buildscript {
  repositories {
    mavenLocal ()
    mavenCentral ()
    maven { url "https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/" }
  }
  dependencies {
    classpath 'com.android.tools.build:gradle:1.5.0'
    classpath 'com.mobidevelop.robovm:robovm-gradle-plugin:2.1.0'
  }
}

allprojects {
  apply plugin: "eclipse"
  apply plugin: "idea"

  version = '1.0'
  ext {
    appName = "game"
    gdxVersion = '1.9.3'
    roboVMVersion = '2.1.0'
  }

  repositories {
    mavenLocal ()
    mavenCentral ()
    maven { url "https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/" }
    maven { url "https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/releases/" }
  }
}

project (":desktop") {
  apply plugin: "java"


  dependencies {
    compile project (":core")
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-backend-lwjgl:$gdxVersion"
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-desktop"
  }
}

project (":android") {
  apply plugin: "android"

  configurations { natives }

  dependencies {
    compile project (":core")
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-backend-android:$gdxVersion"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-armeabi"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-armeabi-v7a"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-x86"
  }
}

project (":ios") {
  apply plugin: "java"
  apply plugin: "robovm"


  dependencies {
    compile project (":core")
    compile "com.mobidevelop.robovm:robovm-rt:${roboVMVersion}"
    compile "com.mobidevelop.robovm:robovm-cocoatouch:${roboVMVersion}"
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-backend-robovm:$gdxVersion"
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-ios"
  }
}

project (":core") {
  apply plugin: "java"


  dependencies {
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx:$gdxVersion"
  }
}

tasks.eclipse.doLast {
  delete ".project"
}
```
#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies

OS: OS X 10.11.4 (El Capitan)
Java: 1.8.0_72
Project Language Level: 1.7
LibGDX: 1.9.3, 1.9.4-SNAPSHOT
RoboVM: 2.1.0, 2.2.0-SNAPSHOT
RoboVM Gradle Plugin: 2.1.0, 2.2.0-SNAPSHOT
Android Build Tools 23.0.1, 23.0.2
Android: 20, 23
Android Gradle Plugin: 1.5.0, 2.1.0
#### Stacktrace

data.title: Auto search project for GdxTest

This adds few tests to the list.

data.title: onPause() not called on android 6.0.1 Nexus 5
data.body:
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.
#### Issue details

On libgdx 1.9.1 (haven't tested on other versions) it seems that AndroidGraphics.pause() kills the running process because pause doesn't get set to false by onDrawFrame() and it timeouts.

Normally, from what I have seen when running an emulator, clicking the HOME button when in a libgdx application calls AndroidApplication.onPause() and AFTER that it kills the render surface. But on a Nexus 5 with latest updates (android 6.0.1 marshmallow), onPause() is called after onDrawFrame() stops being called, meaning that pause = false never gets called, so after a timeout of 4000 ms the process gets killed.
#### Reproduction steps/code

Put a breakpoint in AndroidApplication.onPause() and check if onDrawFrame() still called after the breakpoint hits. On nexus 5 android 6.0.1 you will notice that the rendersurface is destroyed before onPause() gets called, while in the emulator it's the other way around. This bug could happen on other devices as well but I only have a nexus 5 at hand right now.
#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies

1.9.1 possibly on other versions
#### Please select the affected platforms
- [x ] Android
- [ ] iOS
- [ ] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

Assetmanager not loading files that load perfectly with standard FileHandles
data.body:
There seems to be an issue with the AssetManager when loading a particleeffect file on Android, probably to do with Android studio:

`ParticleEffectLoader.ParticleEffectLoadParameter loadParam = new ParticleEffectLoader.ParticleEffectLoadParameter(particleSystem.getBatches());
            ParticleEffectLoader loader = new ParticleEffectLoader(new InternalFileHandleResolver());
            Assets.instance.assetManager.setLoader(ParticleEffect.class, loader);
            Assets.instance.assetManager.load("bb.pfx", ParticleEffect.class, loadParam);
            Assets.instance.assetManager.finishLoading();
effect1=Assets.instance.assetManager.get("bb.pfx",ParticleEffect.class).copy();`

Will result in an Asset Not Loaded Exception only on Android.
I can check AND read the file because:

`FileHandle file = Gdx.files.internal("bb.pfx");
            String text = file.readString();`

Results in a String with the file contents.
#### Reproduction steps/code

Create a new project and use a particleEffect to load with the assetmanager
#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies

I am using the latest version of libgdx from the gradle setup.
#### Stacktrace

`FATAL EXCEPTION: GLThread 165
                                                                      Process: bvo.games.colorspace, PID: 13910

data.title: SpriteBatch#draw draws nothing and gives no error if very high rotation value is passed
Small fixes for JavaDoc in Body.java
data.body: Spell checking and some in-file consistence for the method headers.

data.title: Fix typo in RandomXS128.java
data.body: getState(int) javadoc contains "seed **muse** be 0 or 1"

data.title: Make addAsset public to avoid inheritance just to access this method
data.body: Don't know what to say more, this is a simple change to make this method more easy to use.

data.title: OS detection (non-breaking)
data.body:
This PR adds OS detection to all backends, without breaking the previous enums like ApplicationType.

With this the OS can be queried by calling `Gdx.app.getSystemType()`. The supported systems are:
`Windows, Linux, OSX, Android, iOS, BlackBerry10`

The Android backend is able to differentiate between Android and BlackBerry10, just like GWT can detect all the systems in the enum.
The desktop backends (LWJGL, LWJGL3, JGLFW) are able to differentiate between Windows, OSX and Linux.

data.title: Removed Angle from GraphicsType
Add window size limits to LWJGL 3 app and window configurations.
data.body: Making very nice GLFW feature available.

data.title: Unable to copy internal directory from desktop jar
data.body:
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.
#### Issue details

I am working on the desktop version and attempting to copy an internal directory named default to be a local directory named "addons/default". However it fails to copy and throws an exception. This code is being run with the dist jar for desktop.
#### Reproduction steps/code
1. Create directory in assets named default, add some sub dirs
2. Add following code

``` java
        FileHandle addonsLocalDir = Gdx.files.local("addons");
        if(!addonsLocalDir.exists()) {
            addonsLocalDir.mkdirs();
            FileHandle addons = Gdx.files.internal("default");
            System.out.println("exists: " + addons.exists());
            System.out.println("name:  " + addons.name());
            System.out.println("isDir: " + addons.isDirectory());
            addons.copyTo(addonsLocalDir);
        }
```
1. Package code using desktop dist
2. Run Game
#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies

libgdx: 1.9.2
Version: Desktop
#### Stacktrace

``` java

name:  default
isDir: false
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Error copying source file: default (Internal)
To destination: addons\default (Local)

Caused by: com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Error stream writing to file: addons\default (Local)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle.write(FileHandle.java:296)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle.copyFile(FileHandle.java:682)
        ... 5 more
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at java.io.FilterInputStream.read(Unknown Source)
        at java.io.FilterInputStream.read(Unknown Source)

```

data.title: Implemented OS detection
data.body:
This PR adds the capability of querying the Application objects for the OS they're running on.
This also replaces the the `ApplicationType.Android` and `ApplicationType.iOS` with a `ApplicationType.Mobile`, as now the OS choice is delegated to `Application.getOS()`

data.title: support both width, height scale for the tile cell
data.body: Current `OrthogonalTiledMapRenderer` class only supports an uniform scale parameter for the cells.  Sometimes, we want to show the tile map in the whole screen, this usually need to use different scale values.

data.title: Add RGB 255 support for Color API
data.body: Currently, Color class can only be used with float values and if working with RGB, one must always use (value / 255) to convert to float value. It would be nice to have the Color class API directly working with RGB 255 integer values.
